abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings of the Beira Transport Corridor
            Project for Mozambique are: overall outcome of the project
            is rated satisfactory, performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower was also rated as satisfactory. Some of the lessons
            learned are: 1) ownership is an important element that
            contributes significantly to effective project
            implementation and to the achievement of its objectives.
            With the project under effective control of Beira Corridor
            Authority (BCA), it could monitor its implementation
            effectively, despite a complex multi-donor and multi-purpose
            environment; 2) to be effective; a restructuring process
            should focus on the entire organization of a corporation,
            even when different units are geographically separated.
            Trying to reform Caminhos de Ferro de Mocambique (Centro)
            (CFM(C)), a part of CFM, while keeping the rest of the
            organization with the same old heavy structure and system,
            was a major constraint in implementing the project; 3) in
            order to secure commercial viability and long-term financial
            sustainability of ports and railways, future projects need
            to consider involvement of private sector through all
            possible means including long-term concessions. Complex
            bureaucratic structures and systems, rigid rules and
            procedures, and continuing government interference make it
            almost impossible for fundamental reforms to be achieved
            within the framework of public ownership and management; and
            4) a project design must be flexible enough to adjust to
            changes in the business environment and lessen the risk of
            non-materialization of assumptions. In particular, the
            underlying assumptions must be continuously and critically
            reviewed in order to ensure a realistic basis for project
            dimensioning. The design of the project was too risky to
            achieve its objectives since it focused mostly on the
            traffic forecasts that did not occur. The investment level
            could have been reduced or, at least, considerable part of
            it could have been phased over a longer period and made
            contingent upon increase in traffic.
